blurb:
I am a seventh year PhD Candidate at the UC Berkeley School of Information co-advised by Jenna Burrell and Joshua Blumenstock.

My research lies at the intersection of human-computer interaction (HCI), tech policy, and ethical AI. I focus on bridging technical teams, policymakers, and individuals with lived expertise to inform the design of more just, equitable, and effective sociotechnical systems. I use qualitative methods to understand the perspectives and experiences of impacted communities, and leverage storytelling to influence the design of technical systems and the policies that surround their use. I have developed several new methods that leverage visuals and storytelling as a way to enable people, many with low literacy and limited formal education, to provide meaningful input on technical system design. I have conducted empirical studies in rural villages in Togo, rural ranching communities in the United States, with users on Tiwtter, and among tech workers at large engineering organizations.

I received my B.A. summa cum laude in Sociology from NYU. Advised by Deirdre Royster and Ruth Horowitz, my undergrad thesis explored racial inequalities in the US criminal legal system.

Beyond academia, I worked at an acquired tech startup, plaintiff's employment law firm, and spent four summers interning at Microsoft where I helped develop a responsible AI maturity model, tooling to support red teaming, and worked on Copilot.

At UC Berkeley, I am affiliated with the Global Policy Lab, AI Policy Hub, and Algorithmic Fairness and Opacity Group (AFOG).

★ I am on the academic job market (for tenure track positions and postdocs) in 2024-2025!
